title: God's Judgment on Nineveh
shortSummary: Nahum chapter 1 pronounces God's powerful judgment against Nineveh, the capital of Assyria, highlighting His justice, wrath, and sovereignty over all creation. The chapter contrasts God's patience with His certainty to punish the wicked and deliver His people, offering hope to Judah amid impending destruction of their oppressors.
timeline: c. 7th century BC, during the decline of the Assyrian Empire, prior to the fall of Nineveh in 612 BC

keyCharacters.name: Nahum
keyCharacters.description: The prophet from Elkosh who delivers God's vision and message of judgment against Nineveh.

keyCharacters.name: Nineveh
keyCharacters.description: The capital city of Assyria, known for its wickedness and oppression, which is the subject of Nahum's prophecy.

keyCharacters.name: Judah
keyCharacters.description: The southern kingdom of Israel, addressed as the recipient of God's promise of peace and protection from their enemies.

definitions.definition: God's righteous jealousy refers to His zeal to protect His honor and holiness against idolatry and sin.
To take vengeance or execute justice against one's adversaries, demonstrating God's role as a righteous judge.
The designation of Nahum's origin, likely a town named Elkosh, identifying the prophet's background.
A metaphor for overwhelming and unstoppable divine judgment that destroys the wicked completely.

outline.heading: Introduction and Divine Jealousy (Nahum 1:1-2)
outline.description: The chapter opens with the burden against Nineveh and introduces God's jealous nature and His fierce vengeance against His enemies.

outline.heading: God’s Sovereignty Over Nature and Judgment (Nahum 1:3-6)
outline.description: God’s power is displayed through control over natural forces, emphasizing His ability to execute judgment that none can withstand.

outline.heading: God’s Goodness and Assurance to the Faithful (Nahum 1:7)
outline.description: Despite His wrath, God is a refuge and protector for those who trust in Him, providing comfort amid coming judgment.

outline.heading: The Coming Destruction of Nineveh (Nahum 1:8-14)
outline.description: The prophecy details the total destruction of Nineveh, describing the certainty of its ruin and the end of its idolatry and oppression.

outline.heading: The Promise of Peace for Judah (Nahum 1:15)
outline.description: The chapter closes with a message of hope, announcing the arrival of one who brings good news of peace and protection for Judah.

application: Trust in God as your refuge during times of trouble, knowing He is both just and merciful.
Recognize that God’s patience has limits and that persistent wickedness will face His righteous judgment.
Rejoice in the peace God promises to those who remain faithful and obedient to Him.
Commit to proclaiming the good news of God’s salvation and peace, just as the messenger in verse 15.

keyVerses.text: The LORD is slow to anger, and great in power, and will not at all acquit the wicked: the LORD hath his way in the whirlwind and in the storm, and the clouds are the dust of his feet.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s perfect balance of patience and power, assuring that justice will ultimately prevail.

keyVerses.text: The LORD is good, a strong hold in the day of trouble; and he knoweth them that trust in him.
keyVerses.significance: It offers comfort by affirming God’s goodness and protection for those who place their trust in Him.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD hath given a commandment concerning thee, that no more of thy name be sown: out of the house of thy gods will I cut off the graven image and the molten image: I will make thy grave; for thou art vile.
keyVerses.significance: This verse declares the finality of God’s judgment against idolatry and wickedness in Nineveh.

keyVerses.text: Behold upon the mountains the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace! O Judah, keep thy solemn feasts, perform thy vows: for the wicked shall no more pass through thee; he is utterly cut off.
keyVerses.significance: It concludes with a hopeful promise of peace and restoration for God’s people, encouraging worship and faithfulness.
